Afghan governor little Amish all is
referring to a nighttime raid in his
province by American Special Forces in
search of Taliban On January 7th such
raids have become an increasing focus of
complaint as the Obama administration
prepares to send as many as 30,000
additional American forces to
Afghanistan this year many fear that
more troops in the country will mean
more violence and more civilian
casualties as many as 4,000 civilians
were killed in fighting last year New
York Times correspondent Carlotta gall
reports on the raid in the village of
Muhammad in eastern Afghanistan they
killed my brother right in the doorway
one of the villagers wounded in the
attack said he responded to screams for
help from a neighbor when I came out
from sleeping to the terrorists I heard
a woman screaming
she said thieves have come in take me
out I shouted to the woman asking where
the thieves were then I looked down the
Americans said something in English in
shock people thought the are thieves
they are robbers or mothers so everybody
came up out of their house with her with
a with a rifle even some of them had
come with with with knives to just kill
it give the robber but later on whoever
comes out of the house with a weapon he
is short
because they the American forces have
night-vision
devices so they could see them that
there is a person within me the clashing
of running toward incident Governor
Marshall says that in this case the
tactics of the Special Forces enraged
the villagers the tactics included
breaking down doors and rousting people
from their sleep with dogs
the governor says 19 villagers were
killed only six of them Taliban our
costumes our values badly neglected and
that's why there were civilian
casualties if it was coordinated with us
if there wasn't at one officer with him
NP or anybody this would have not had
happened after seven years of war Afghan
patience with the raids is wearing thin
but the mistrust cuts both ways for
Afghan villagers they are reluctant to
share information with forces who tick
in their doors at night American special
forces say they need to act quickly on
tips and they are sometimes reluctant to
share their information with villagers
who may be sympathetic to the Taliban or
even with Afghan forces when asked about
this raid the US military spokesman
Colonel Gerry O'Hara did not believe
that the Afghans were acting against who
they thought were thieves quote I'm not
buying that these people were acting as
centuries Governor Michele and other
governors say incidents like the village
raid only add to the mistrust if you
want to win the war you have to win the
hearts and minds of people indeed big
enemy now with these kind of incidents
actually we lose the earth and minds of
people and then I had earned the hurts
and - 90 % but now I lost it 30 percent
again
